div.p: THE KNIGHT OF the Burning Pestle.

quote.l: Ad libros & ad haec Musarum dona vocares:
Boeotum in crasso iurares aëre natos.
quote.bibl: Horat. in Epist. ad Oct. Aug.

div.p: LONDON, Printed for Walter Burre, and are to be sold at the signe of the Crane in Paules Church-yard. 1613.

div.head: TO HIS MANY WAIES ENDEERED friend Maister Robert Keysar.
div.p:
SIR, this vnfortunate child, who in eight daies (as lately I haue learned) was begot and borne soone after, was by his parents (perhaps because hee was so vnlike his brethren) exposed to the wide world, who for want of iudgement, or not vnderstanding the priuy marke of Ironie about it (which shewed it was no of-spring of any vulgar braine) vtterly reiected it: so that for want of acceptance it was euen ready to giue vp the Ghost, and was in danger to haue bene smothered in perpetuall obliuion, if you (out of your direct antipathy to ingratitude) had not bene moued both to relieue and cherish it: wherein I must needs commend both your iudgement, vnderstanding, and singular loue to good wits; you afterwards sent it to mee, yet being an infant and somewhat ragged, I haue fostred it priuately in my bosome these two yeares,
and now to shew, my loue returne it to you, clad in good lasting cloaths, which scarce memory will weare out, and able to speake for it selfe; and withall, as it telleth mee, desirous to try his fortune in the world, where if yet it be welcome, both father and foster-father, nurse and child, haue their desired end. If it bee slighted or traduced, it hopes his father will beget him a yonger brother, who shall reuenge his quarrell, and challenge the world either of fond and meerely literall interpretation, or illiterate misprision. Perhaps it will be thought to bee of the race of Don Quixote: we both may confidently sweare, it is his elder aboue a yeare; and therefore may (by vertue of his birth-right) challenge the wall of him. I doubt not but they will meet in their aduentures, and I hope the breaking of one staffe will make them friends; and perhaps they will conbine themselues, and trauell through the world to seeke their aduentures. So I commit him to his good fortune, and my selfe to your loue.

div.head: The famous Historie Of the Knight of the burning PESTLE.
div.l: FRom all that's neere the Court, from all that's great
Within the compasse of the Citty-wals,
We now haue brought our Sceane.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Hold your peace good-man boy.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: What do you meane sir?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: That you haue no good meaning: This seuen yeares there hath beene playes at this house, I haue obserued it, you haue still girds at Citizens; and now you call your play, The London Marchant. Downe with your Title boy, downe with your Title.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: Are you a member of the noble Citty?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: I am.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: And a Free-man?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Yea, and a Grocer.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: So Grocer, then by your sweet fauour, we intend no abuse to the Citty.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p:
No sir, yes sir, if you were not resolu'd to play the Iacks, what need you study for new subiects, purposely to abuse your betters? why could not you be contented, as well as others, with the legend of Whittington, or the life & death of sir Thomas Gresham? with the building of the Royall Exchange?
or the story of Queene Elenor, with the rearing of London bridge vpon wool-sackes?

sp.speaker: Prol.
sp.p: You seeme to bee an vnderstanding man: what would you haue vs do sir?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Why present something notably in honour of the Commons of the Citty.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: Why what doe you say to the life and death of fat Drake, or the repairing of Fleet-priuies?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: I do not like that, but I will haue a Citizen, and hee shall be of my owne trade.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: Oh you should haue told vs your minde a moneth since, our play is ready to begin now.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: 'Tis all one for that, I will haue a Grocer, and he shall do admirable things.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: What will you haue him do?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Marry I will haue him—

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Husband, husband.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.p: Peace mistresse.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Hold thy peace Rafe, I know what I do I warrant tee. Husband, husband.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: What sayst thou cunny?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Let him kill a Lyon with a pestle husband, let him kill a Lyon with a pestle.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: So he shall, Il'e haue him kill a Lyon with a pestle.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Husband, shall I come vp husband?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: I cunny. Rafe helpe your mistresse this way: pray gentlemen make her a little roome, I pray you sir lend me your hand to helpe vp my wife: I thanke you sir. So.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: By your leaue Gentlemen all, Im'e somthing troublesome, Im'e a stranger here, I was nere at one of these playes as they say, before; but I should haue seene Iane Shore once, aud my husband hath promised me any time this Twelue-moneth to carry me to the Bold Beauchams, but in truth he did not, I pray you beare with me.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Boy, let my wife and I haue a cupple stooles, and then begin, and let the Grocer do rare things.

sp.speaker: Prol.
sp.p:
But sir, we haue neuer a boy to play him, euery
one hath a part already.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Husband, husband, for Gods sake let Rafe play him, beshrew mee if I do not thinke hee will goe beyond them all.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Well remembred wife, come vp Rafe: Il'e tell you Gentlemen, let them but lend him a suit of reparrell, and necessaries, and by Gad, if any of them all blow winde in the taile on him, Il'e be hang'd.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I pray you youth let him haue a suit of reparrell, Il'e be sworne Gentlemen, my husband tels you true, hee will act you sometimes at our house, that all the neighbours cry out on him: hee will fetch you vp a couraging part so in the garret, that we are all as feard I warrant you, that wee quake againe: wee'l feare our children with him if they bee neuer so vn-ruly, do but cry, Rafe comes, Rafe comes to them, and they'l be as quyet as Lambes. Hold vp thy head Rafe, shew the Gentlemen what thou canst doe, speake a huffing part, I warrant you the Gentlemen will accept of it.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Do Rafe, do.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.l: By heauen me thinkes it were an easie leap
To plucke bright honour from the pale-fac'd Moone,
Or diue into the bottome of the sea,
Where neuer fathame line touch't any ground,
And plucke vp drowned honor from the lake of hell.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: How say you Gentlemen, is it not as I told you?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Nay Gentlemen, hee hath playd before, my husband sayes, Musidorus before the Wardens of our Company.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: I, and hee should haue playd Ieronimo with a Shooe-maker for a wager.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: He shall haue a suite of apparrell if he will go in.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: In Rafe, in Rafe, and set out the Grocery in their kinde, if thou lou'st me.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I warrant our Rafe will looke finely when hee's drest.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: But what will you haue it cal'd?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: The Grocers honour.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: Me thinks The Knight of the burning Pestle were better.

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.p: Il'e be sworn husband, thats as good a name as can be.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Let it be so, begin, begin, my wife and I wil sit downe.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: I pray you do.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: What stately mucsike haue you? you haue shawmes.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: Shawnes? no.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: No? Im'e a thiefe if my minde did not giue me so. Rafe playes a stately part, and he must needs haue shawnes: Il'e be at the charge of them my selfe, rather then wee'l be without them.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: So you are like to be.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Why and so I will be: ther's two shillings, let's haue the waits of South-warke, they are as rare fellowes as any are in England; and that will fetch them all or'e the water with a vengeance, as if they were mad.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: You shall haue them: will you sit downe then?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: I, come wife.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Sit you merry all Gentlemen, Im'e bold to sit amongst you for my ease.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: From all that's neere the Court, from all that's great.
Within the compasse of the Citty-walles,
We now haue brought our Sceane: flye farre from hence
All priuate taxes, immodest phrases,
What ere may but shew like vicious:
For wicked mirth neuer true pleasure brings,
But honest minds are pleas'd with honest things.
Thus much for that we do: but for Rafes part
You must answere for your selfe.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Take you no care for Rafe, hee'l discharge himselfe I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I faith Gentlemen Il'e giue my word for Rafe.

div.head: Actus primi,
Scoena prima.
div.stage: Enter Marchant, and Iasper his Prentice.

sp.speaker: March.
sp.l: Sirrah, Il'e make you know you are my Prentice,
And whom my charitable loue redeem'd
Euen from the fall of fortune, gaue thee heate
And growth, to be what now thou art, new cast thee,
Adding the trust of all I haue at home,
In forren Staples, or vpon the Sea
To thy direction, ti'de the good opinions
Both of my selfe and friends to thy endeauours,
So faire were thy beginnings, but with these,
As I remember, you had neuer charge,
To loue your Maisters daughter, and euen then,
When I had found a wealthy husband for her,
I take it, sir, you had not; but how euer,
I'le breake the necke of that commission,
And make you know you are but a Merchants Factor.

sp.speaker: Iasp.
sp.l: Sir, I do liberally confesse I am yours,
Bound, both by loue and duty, to your seruice;
In which, my labour hath bene all my profit;
I haue not lost in bargaine, nor delighted
To weare your honest gaines vpon my backe,
Nor haue I giuen a pencion to my bloud,
Or lauishly in play consum'd your stocke.
These, and the miseries that do attend them,
I dare, with innocence, proclaime are strangers
To all my temperate actions; for your daughter,
If there be any loue, to my deseruings,
Borne by her vertuous selfe, I cannot stop it?
Nor, am I able to refraine her wishes.
She's priuate to her selfe and best of knowledge,
Whom she'le make so happy as to sigh for.
Besides, I cannot thinke you meane to match her,
Vnto a felow of so lame a presence,
One that hath little left of Nature in him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: 'Tis very well sir, I can tell your wisedome
How all this shall bee cur'd.

sp.speaker: Iasp.
sp.l: Your care becomes you.

sp.speaker: March.
sp.l: And thus it must be sir, I heere discharge you
My house and seruice, take your liberty,
And when I want a sonne I'le send for you.

sp.speaker: Iasp.
sp.l: These be the faire rewards of them that loue.
O you that liue in freedome neuer proue
The trauell of a mind led by desire.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Why, how now friend, struck with my fathers thunder?

sp.speaker: Iasp.
sp.l: Strucke and strucke dead vnlesse the remedy
Be full of speede and vertue; I am now,
What I expected long, no more your fathers.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: But mine.

sp.speaker: Iasp.
sp.l: But yours, and onely yours I am,
That's all I haue to keepe mee from the Statute,
You dare be constant still.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: O feare me not,
In this I dare be better then a woman.
Nor shall his anger, nor his offers moue me,
Were they both equall to a Princes power.

sp.speaker: Iasp.
sp.l: You know my riuall?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Yes and loue him deerly
Euen as I loue an ague, or foule weather,
I prethee Iasper feare him not.

sp.speaker: Iasp.
sp.l: O no,
I do not meane to do him so much kindnesse,
But to our owne desires, you know the plot
We both agreed on.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Yes, and will performe
My part exactly.

sp.speaker: Iasp.
sp.l: I desire no more,
Fare-well, and keepe my heart, 'tis yours.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: I take it,
He must do miracles makes me forsake it.

sp.speaker: Cittiz.
sp.p: Fye vpon am little infidels, what a matters here now? well, I'le be hang'd for a halfe-penny, if there be not some abomination knauery in this Play, well, let'em looke toot, Rafe must come, and if there be any tricks a brewing,—

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Let'em brew and bake too husband, a Gods name, Rafe will find all out I warrant you, and they were older then they are, I pray my pretty youth is Rafe ready.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: He will be presently.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Now I pray you make my commendations vnto him, and withall carry him this sticke of Licoras, tell him his Mistresse sent it him, and bid him bite a peece, 'twill open his pipes the better, say.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Come sir, shee's yours, vpon my faith she's yours
You haue my hand, for other idle lets
Betweene your hopes and her, thus, with a wind
They are scattered and no more: my wanton Prentice,
That like a bladder, blew himselfe with loue,
I haue let out, and sent him to discouer
New Maisters yet vnknowne.

sp.speaker: Humf.
sp.l: I thanke you sir,
Indeed I thanke you sir, and ere I stir
It shall bee knowne, how euer you do deeme,
I am of gentle bloud and gentle seeme.

sp.speaker: March.
sp.l: O sir, I know it certaine.

sp.speaker: Humf.
sp.l: Sir my friend,
Although, as Writers say, all things haue end,
And that we call a pudding, hath his two
O let it not seeme strange I pray to you,
If in this bloudy simile, I put
My loue, more endlesse, then fraile things or gut.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Husband, I prethee sweete lambe tell me one thing, But tell mee truely: stay youths I beseech you, till I question my husband.

sp.speaker: Citiz.
sp.p: What is it mouse?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Sirrah, didst thou euer see a prettier child? how it behaues it selfe, I warrant yee, and speakes, and lookes, and pearts vp the head? I pray you brother, with your fauor, were you neuer none of M. Monkesters schollars?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Chicken, I prethee heartely containe thy selfe, the childer are pretty childer, but when Rafe comes, Lambe.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I when Rafe comes conny; well my youth, you may proceed

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Wel sir, you know my loue, and rest, I hope,
Assur'd of my consent, get but my daughters,
And wed her when you please; you must be bold,
And clap in close vnto her, come, I know
You haue language good enough to win a wench.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: A whoreson tyrant has ben an old stringer in's daies I warrant him.

sp.speaker: Humf.
sp.l: I take your gentle offer and withall
Yeeld loue againe for loue reciprocall.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What Luce within there.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Cal'd you sir?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I did.
Giue entertainement to this Gentleman
And see you bee not froward: to her sir,
My presence will but bee an eye-soare to you.

sp.speaker: Humf.
sp.l: Faire Mistresse Luce, how do you, are you well?
Giue me your hand and then I pray you tell,
How doth your little sister, and your brother?
And whether you loue me or any other.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Sir, these are quickely answered.

sp.speaker: Humf.
sp.l: So they are.
Where women are not cruel: but how farre
Is it now distant from this place we are in,
Vnto that blessed place your fathers warren.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: What makes you thinke of that sir?

sp.speaker: Humf.
sp.l: Euen that face
For stealing Rabbets whilome in that place,
God Cupid, or the Keeper, I know not whether
Vnto my cost and charges brought you thither,
And there began.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Your game sir.

sp.speaker: Humf.
sp.l: Let no game,
Or any thing that tendeth to the same.
Bee euermore remembred, thou faire killer
For whom I sate me downe and brake my Tiller.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: There's a kind Gentleman, I warrant you, when will you do as much for me George?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Beshrew me sir, I am sorry for your losses,
But as the prouerbe saies, I cannot cry,
I would you had not seene me.

sp.speaker: Humf.
sp.l: So would I.
Vnlesse you had more maw to do me good.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Why, cannot this strange passion be withstood,
Send for a Constable and raise the Towne.

sp.speaker: Humf.
sp.l: O no, my valiant loue will batter downe
Millions of Constables, and put to flight,
Euen that great watch of Mid-summer day at night.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Beshrew me sir, 'twere good I yeelded then,
Weake women cannot hope, where valiant men
Haue no resistance.

sp.speaker: Humf.
sp.l: Yeeld then, I am full
Of pitty, though I say it, and can pull
Out of my pocket, thus, a paire of gloues,
Looke Lucy, looke, the dogs tooth, nor the Doues
Are not so white as these; and sweete they bee,
And whipt about with silke, as you may see.
If you desire the price, sute from your eie,
A beame to this place, and you shall espie
F. S. which is to say, my sweetest hony,
They cost me three and two pence, or no mony.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Well sir, I take them kindly, and I thanke you,
What would you more?

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: Nothing.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Why then fare-well.

sp.speaker: Humf.
sp.l: Nor so, nor so, for Lady I must tell,
Before we part, for what we met together,
God grant me time, and patience, and faire weather.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Speake and declare your minde in termes so briefe.

sp.speaker: Humf.
sp.l: I shall, then first and formost for reliefe
I call to you, I if that you can affoord it,
I care not at what price, for on my word, it
Shall be repaid againe, although it cost me
More then I'le speake of now, for loue hath tost me,
In furious blanket like a Tennis ball,
And now I rise aloft, and now I fall.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Alas good Gentleman, alas the day.

sp.speaker: Humf.
sp.l: I thanke you hartely, and as I say,
Thus do I still continue without rest,
I'th' morning like a man, at night a beast,
Roaring and bellowing myne owne disquiet,
That much I feare, forsaking of my diet,
Will bring me presently to that quandary,
I shall bid all adeiw:

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Now by S. Mary
That were great pitty.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: So it were beshrew me,
Then ease me lusty Luce, and pitty shew me.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Why sir, you know my will is nothing worth
Without my fathers grant, get his consent,
And then you may with assurance try me.

sp.speaker: Humf.
sp.l: The Worshipfull your sire will not deny me.
For I haue askt him, and he hath repli'd,
Sweete Maister Humfrey, Luce shall be thy Bride.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Sweete Maister Humfrey then I am content.

sp.speaker: Humf.
sp.l: And so am I intruth.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Yet take me with you,
There is another clause must be annext,
And this it is, I swore and will performe it;
No man shall euer ioy me as his wife
But he that stole me hence, if you dare venter
I am yours; you need not feare, my father loues you,
If not farewell for euer.

sp.speaker: Humf.
sp.l: Stay Nimph, staie,
I haue a double Gelding culored bay,
Sprung by his father from Barbarian kind,
Another for my selfe, though somewhat blind,
Yet true as trusty tree.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: I am satisfied,
And so I giue my hand, our course must lie
Through Waltham Forrest, where I haue a friend
Will entertaine vs, so fare-well sir Humfrey,
And thinke vpon your businesse.

sp.speaker: Humf.
sp.l: Though I die,
I am resolu'd to venter life and lim,
For one so yong, so faire, so kind, so trim.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: By my faith and troth George, and as I am vertuous, it is e'ne the kindest yong man that euer trod on shooe leather, well, go thy waies if thou hast her not, 'tis not thy fault 'faith.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: I prethee mouse be patient, a shall haue her, or i'le make some'em smoake for't.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: That's my good lambe George, fie, this stinking Tobacco kils men, would there were none in England, now I pray Gentlemen, what good does this stinking Tobacco? do you nothing, I warrant you make chimnies a your faces: o husband, husband, now, now, there's Rafe, there's Rafe.

div.stage: Enter Rafe like a Grocerin's shop, with two Prentices Reading Palmerin of England.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Peace foole, let Rafe alone, harke you Rafe; doe not straine your selfe too much at the first, peace, begin Rafe.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.p:
Then Palmerin and Trineus snatching their Launces from their Dwarfes, and clasping their Helmets gallopt amaine after the Gyant, and Palmerin hauing gotten a sight of him, came posting amaine, saying: Stay trayterous thiefe, for thou maist not so carry away her, that is worth the greatest Lord in the world, and with these words gaue him a blow on the shoulder, that he stroake him besides his Elephant, and Trineus comming to the Knight that had Agricola behind him, set him soone besides his horse, with his necke broken in the fall, so that the Princesse getting out of the thronge, betweene ioy and griefe said; all happy Knight, the mirrour of all such as follow Armes, now may I bee well assured of
the loue thou bearest me, I wonder why the Kings doe not raise an army of foureteene or fifteene hundred thousand men, as big as the Army that the Prince of Portigo brought against Rocicler, & destroy these Giants, they do much hurt to wandring Damsels, that go in quest of their Knights.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Faith husband and Rafe saies true, for they say the King of Portugall cannot sit at his meate, but the Giants & the Elfins will come and snatch it from him,

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Hold thy tongue, on Rafe.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.p: And certainely those Knights are much to be commended, who neglecting their possessions, wander with a Squire and a Dwarfe through the Desarts to relieue poore Ladies.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I by my faith are they Rafe, let 'em say what they will, they are indeed, our Knights neglect their possessions well enough, but they do not the rest.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.p: There are no such courteous and faire well spoken Knights in this age, they will call one the sonne of a whore, that Palmerin of England, would haue called faire sir; and one that Rosicler would haue cal'd right beauteous Damsell, they will call dam'd bitch.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I'le be sworne will they Rafe, they haue cal'd mee so an hundred times about a scuruy pipe of Tobacco.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.p: But what braue spirit could be content to sit in his shop with a flappet of wood and a blew apron before him selling Methridatum and Dragons water to visited houses, that might pursue feats of Armes, & through his noble atchieuments procure such a famous history to be written of his heroicke prowesse.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Well said Rafe, some more of those words Rafe.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: They go finely by my troth.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.p:
Why should not I then pursue this course, both for the credit of my selfe and our Company, for amongst all the worthy bookes of Atchieuements I doe not call to minde that I yet read of a Grocer Errant, I will be the said Knight, haue you heard of any, that hath wandred vnfurnished of his Squire and Dwarfe, my elder Prentice
Tim shall be my trusty Squire, and little George my Dwarfe, Hence my blew Aporne, yet in remembrance of my former Trade, vpon my shield shall be purtraide, a burning Pestle, and I will be cal'd the Knight oth burning Pestle.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Nay, I dare sweare thou wilt not forget thy old Trade, thou wert euer meeke.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Anon.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.p: My beloued Squire, & George my Dwarfe, I charge you that from hence-forth you neuer call me by any other name, but the Right Courteous and Valiant Knight of the burning Pestle, and that you neuer call any female by the name of a woman or wench, but faire Ladie, if she haue her desires, if not distressed Damsell, that you call all Forrests & Heaths Desarts, and all horses Palfries.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: This is very fine, faith, do the Gentlemen like Rafe, thinke you, husband?

sp.speaker: Cittiz.
sp.p: I, I warrant thee, the Plaiers would giue all the shooes in their shop for him.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.p: My beloued Squire Tim, stand out, admit this were a Desart, and ouer it a Knight errant pricking, and I should bid you inquire of his intents, what would you say?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Sir, my Maister sent me, to know whether you are riding?

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.p: No, thus; faire sir, the Right Courteous and Valiant Knight of the burning Pestle, commanded me to enquire, vpon what aduenture you are bound, whether to relieue some distressed Damsels, or otherwise.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Whoresome blocke-head cannot remember.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I'faith, & Rafe told him on't before, all the Gentlemen heard him, did he not Gentlemen, did not Rafe tel him on't?

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Right Courteous and Valiant Knight of the burning Pestle, here is a distressed Damsell, to haue a halfe penny-worth of pepper.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: That's a good boy, see, the little boy can hit it, by my troth it's a fine child.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.p:
Relieue her with all courteous language, now shut vp shoppe, no more my Prentice, but my trusty
Squire and Dwarfe, I must bespeake my shield and arming-pestle.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Go thy waies Rafe, as Im'e a true man, thou art the best on 'em all.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Rafe, Rafe.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.p: What say you mistresse?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I pre'thee come againe quickly sweet Rafe.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.p: By and by.

div.stage: Enter Iasper, and his mother mistresse Merri-thought.

sp.speaker: Mist. merri.
sp.p: Giue thee my blessing? No, Il'e ner'e giue thee my blessing, Il'e see thee hang'd first; it shall ner'e bee said I gaue thee my blessing, th'art thy fathers owne sonne, of the right bloud of the Merri-thoughts, I may curse the time that er'e I knew thy father, he hath spent all his owne, and mine too, and when I tell him of it, he laughes and dances, and sings, and cryes, A merry heart liues long-a. And thou art a wast-thrift, and art run away from thy maister, that lou'd thee well, and art come to me, and I haue laid vp a little for my yonger sonne Michael, and thou think'st to bezell that, but thou shalt neuer be able to do it. Come hither Michael, come Michael, downe on thy knees, thou shalt haue my blessing.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.p: I pray you mother pray to God to blesse me.

sp.speaker: Mist. merri.
sp.p: God blesse thee: but Iasper shal neuer haue my blessing, he shall be hang'd first, shall hee not Michael? how saist thou?

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.p: Yes forsooth mother and grace of God.

sp.speaker: Mist. merri.
sp.p: That's a good boy.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I faith it's a fine spoken child.

sp.speaker: Iasp.
sp.l: Mother, though you forget a parents loue,
I must preserue the duty of a child.
I ran not from my maister, nor returne
To haue your stocke maintaine my Idlenesse.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Vngracious childe I warrant him, harke how hee chops logicke with his mother: thou hadst best tell her she lyes, do tell her she lyes.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p:
If hee were my sonne, I would hang him vp by the
heeles, and flea him, and salt him, whoore-sonne haltersacke.

sp.speaker: Iasp.
sp.l: My comming onely is to begge your loue,
Which I must euer, though I neuer gaine it,
And howsoeuer you esteeme of me,
There is no drop of bloud hid in these veines,
But I remember well belongs to you
That brought me forth, and would be glad for you
To rip them all againe, and let it out.

sp.speaker: Mist. merri.
sp.p: I faith I had sorrow enough for thee (God knowes) but Il'e hamper thee well enough: get thee in thou vagabond, get thee in, and learne of thy brother Michael.

sp.speaker: Old merri. within.
sp.p: Nose, nose, iolly red nose, and who gaue thee this iolly red nose?

sp.speaker: Mist. merri.
sp.l: Harke, my husband hee's singing and hoiting,
And Im'e faine to carke and care, and all little enough.
Husband, Charles, Charles Merithought.

sp.speaker: Old merri.
sp.l: Nutmegs and Ginger, Cinnamon and Cloues,
And they gaue me this iolly red Nose.

sp.speaker: Mist. merri.
sp.p: If you would consider your state, you would haue little lust to sing, I-wisse.

sp.speaker: Old merri.
sp.p: It should neuer bee considered while it were an estate, if I thought it would spoyle my singing.

sp.speaker: Mist. merri.
sp.p: But how wilt thou do Charles, thou art an old man, and thou canst not worke, and thou hast not fortie shillings left, and thou eatest good meat, and drinkest good drinke, and laughest?

sp.speaker: Old merri.
sp.p: And will do.

sp.speaker: Mist. merri.
sp.p: But how wilt thou come by it Charles?

sp.speaker: Old merri.
sp.p:
How? why how haue I done hitherto this forty yeares? I neuer came into my dining roome, but at eleuen & six a clocke, I found excellent meat and drinke a'th table, my clothes were neuer worne out, but next morning a Taylor brought me a new suit; and without question it will be so euer: vse makes perfectnesse. If all should faile, it is but a little
straining my selfe extraordinary, & laugh my selfe to death.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: It's a foolish old man this: is not he George?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Yes Cunny.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Giue me a peny i'th purse while I liue George.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: I by Ladie cunnie, hold thee there.

sp.speaker: Mist. merri.
sp.p: Well Charles, you promis'd to prouide for Iasper, and I haue laid vp for Michael, I pray you pay Iasper his portion, hee's come home, and hee shall not consume Michaels stocke: he saies his maister turnd him away, but I promise you truly, I thinke he ran away.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: No indeed mistresse Merrithought, though he bee a notable gallowes, yet Il'e assure you his maister did turne him away, euen in this place 'twas I'faith within this halfe houre, about his daughter, my husband was by.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Hang him rougue, he seru'd him well enough: loue his maisters daughter! by my troth Cunnie if there were a thousand boies, thou wouldst spoile them all with taking their parts, let his mother alone with him.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I George, but yet truth is truth.

sp.speaker: Old merri.
sp.p: Where is Iasper, hee's welcome how euer, call him in, hee shall haue his portion, is he merry?

sp.speaker: Mist. merri.
sp.p: I foule chiue him, he is too merrie. Iasper, Michael.

sp.speaker: Old merri.
sp.p: Welcome Iasper, though thou runst away, welcome, God blesse thee: 'tis thy mothers minde thou should'st receiue thy portion; thou hast beene abroad, and I hope hast learn'd experience enough to gouerne it, thou art of sufficient yeares, hold thy hand: one, two, three, foure, fiue, sixe, seuen, eight, nine, there's ten shillings for thee, thrust thy selfe into the world with that, and take some setled course, if fortune crosse thee, thou hast a retiring place, come home to me, I haue twentie shillings left, bee a good husband, that is, weare ordinary clothes, eate the best meate, and drinke the best drinke, bee merrie, and giue to the poore, and beleeue me, thou hast no end of thy goods.

sp.speaker: Iasp.
sp.l: Long may you liue free from all thought of ill,
And long haue cause to be thus merry still.
But father?

sp.speaker: Old merri.
sp.p: No more words Iasper, get thee gone, thou hast my blessing, thy fathers spirit vpon thee. Farewell Iasper, but yet or ere you part (oh cruell!) kisse me, kisse me sweeting, mine owne deere iewell: So, now begone; no words.

sp.speaker: Mis. mer.
sp.p: So Michael, now get thee gone too.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.p: Yes forsooth mother, but Il'e haue my fathers blessing first.

sp.speaker: Mis. mer.
sp.p: No Michael, 'tis now matter for his blessing, thou hast my blessing, begone; Il'e fetch my money & iewels, and follow thee: Il'e stay no longer with him I warrant thee, truly Charles Il'e begone too.

sp.speaker: Old merri.
sp.p: What you will not.

sp.speaker: Mis. merri.
sp.p: Yes indeed will I.

sp.speaker: Old merri.
sp.p: Hey ho, fare-well Nan, Il'e neuer trust wench more againe, if I can.

sp.speaker: Mis. merri.
sp.p: You shall not thinke (when all your owne is gone) to spend that I haue beene scraping vp for Michael.

sp.speaker: Old merri.
sp.p:
Farewell good wife, I expect it not; all I haue to doe in this world, is to bee merry: which I shall, if the ground be not taken from me: and if it be,
When earth and seas from me are rest,
The skyes aloft for me are left.

div.stage: Boy danceth. Musicke. Finis Actus primi.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Il'e be sworne hee's a merry old Gentleman for all that. Harke, harke husband, harke, fiddles, fiddles; now surely they go finely. They say, 'tis present death for these fidlers to tune their Rebeckes before the great Turkes grace, is't not George? But looke, looke, here's a youth dances: now good youth do a turne ath' toe, sweet heart, I'faith Ile haue Rafe come and do some of his Gambols; hee'l ride the wild mare Gentlemen, 'twould do your hearts good to see him. I thanke you kinde youth, pray bid Rafe come.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Peace Cunnie. Sirrah, you scuruie boy, bid the plaiers send Rafe, or by Gods— and they do not, Il'e teare some of their periwigs beside their heads: this is all Riffe Raffe.

div.head: Actus secundi
Scoena prima.

sp.speaker: March.
sp.p: And how faith? how goes it now son Humphrey?

sp.speaker: Humph.
sp.l: Right worshipfull, and my beloued friend
And father deere, this matters at an end.

sp.speaker: March.
sp.l: 'Tis well, it should be so, Im'e glad the girle
Is found so tractable.

sp.speaker: Humph.
sp.l: Nay she must whirle
From hence, and you must winke: for so I say,
The storie tels, to morrow before day.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: George, do'st thou thinke in thy conscience now 'twil be a match? tell me but what thou thinkst sweet rogue, thou seest the poore Gentleman (deere heart) how it labours and throbs I warrant you, to be at rest: Il'e goe moue the father fort.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: No, no, I pre'thee sit still hony-suckle, thoul't spoile all, if he deny him, Il'e bring halfe a dozen good fellows my selfe, & in the shutting of an euening knock't vp, & ther's an end.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Il'e busse thee for that i'faith boy; well George, well, you haue beene a wag in your daies I warrant you: but God forgiue you, and I do with all my heart.

sp.speaker: March.
sp.l: How was it sonne? you told me that to morrow
Before day breake, you must conuey her hence.

sp.speaker: Humph.
sp.l: I must, I must, and thus it is agreed,
Your daughter rides vpon a browne-bay steed,
I on a sorrell, which I bought of Brian,
The honest Host of the red roaring Lion
In Waltham situate: then if you may
Consent in seemely sort, lest by delay,
The fatall sisters come and do the office,
And then you'l sing another song.

sp.speaker: March.
sp.l: Alasse
Why should you be thus full of griefe to me?
That do as willing as your selfe agree
To any thing so it be good and faire,
Then steale her when you will, if such a pleasure
Content you both, I'le sleepe and neuer see it,
To make your ioyes more full, but tell me why
You may not here performe your marriage?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Gods blessing a thy soule old man, i'faith thou art loath to part true hearts, I see, a has her Georg, & I'me as glad on't, well, go thy waies Humphrey, for a faire spoken man, I beleeue thou hast not thy fellow within the wals of London, & I should say the Suburbes too, I should not lie, why dost not reioyce with me George?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.l: If I could but see Raph againe, I were as merry as mine Host i'faith.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: The cause you seeme to aske, I thus declare,
Helpe me ô Muses nine, your daughter sweare
A foolish oath, the more it was the pitty,
Yet none but my selfe within this Citty,
Shall dare to say so, but a bold defiance
Shall meete him, were he of the noble Science.
And yet she sweare, and yet why did she sweare?
Truely I cannot tell, vnlesse it were
For her owne ease, for sure sometimes an oath,
Being sworne thereafter is like cordiall broth.
And this it was shee swore, neuer to marry,
But such a one, whose mighty arme could carry
(As meaning me, for I am such a one)
Her bodily away through sticke and stone,
Till both of vs arriue, at her request,
Some ten miles off, in the wilde Waltham Forrest.

sp.speaker: March.
sp.l: If this be all, you shall not need to feare
Any deniall in your loue, proceed,
I'le neither follow, nor repent the deed.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: Good-night, twenty good-nights, & twenty more.
And 20 more good-nights, that makes three-score.

div.stage: Enter mistresse Mery-thought, and her son Michael.

sp.speaker: Mist. mer.
sp.p: Come Michael, art thou not weary boy?

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.p: No for-sooth mother not I.

sp.speaker: Mist. mer.
sp.p: Where be we now child?

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.p: Indeed for-sooth mother I cannot tell, vnlesse we be at Mile-end, is not all the world Mile-end, Mother?

sp.speaker: Mist. mer.
sp.p: No Michael, not al the world boy, but I can assure thee Michael, Mile-end is a goodly matter, there has bene a pitch-field my child betweene the naughty Spaniels and the English-men, and the Spaniels ran away Michael, and the English-men followed, my neighbour Coxstone was there boy, and kil'd them all with a birding peece.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.p: Mother forsooth.

sp.speaker: Mist. mer.
sp.p: What saies my white boy?

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.p: Shall not my father go with vs too?

sp.speaker: Mist. mer.
sp.p: No Michael, let thy father go snicke-vp, he shall neuer come between a paire of sheets with me againe, while he liues, let him stay at home & sing for his supper boy, come child sit downe, and I'le shew my boy fine knacks indeed, look here Michael, here's a Ring, and here's Bruch, & here's a Bracelet, and here's two Rings more, and here's mony and gold by'th eie my boy.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.p: Shall I haue all this mother?

sp.speaker: Mist. mer.
sp.p: I Michael thou shalt haue all Michael.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: How lik'st thou this wench?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I cannot tell, I would haue Raph, George; I'le see no more else indeed-law, & I pray you let the youths vnderstand so much by word of mouth, for I tell you truely, I'me afraid a my boy, come, come George, let's be merry and wise, the child's a father-lesse child, and say they should put him into a streight paire of Gaskins, 'twere worse then knot-grasse, he would neuer grow after it.

sp.speaker: Cit:
sp.p: Here's Raph, here's Raph.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: How do you Raph? you are welcome Raph, as I may say, it's a good boy, hold vp thy head, and be not afraid, we are thy friends Raph, the Gentlemen will praise thee Raph, if thou plaist thy part with audacity, begin Raph a Gods name.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.p: My trusty Squire vnlace my Helme, giue mee my hat, where are we, or what Desart may this be?

sp.speaker: Dwarfe.
sp.p: Mirrour of Knight-hood, this is, as I take it, the perrilous Waltham downe, In whose bottome stands the inchanted Valley.

sp.speaker: Mist. mer.
sp.p:
O Michael, we are betrai'd, we are betraid here
be Gyants, flie boy, flie boy, flie.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.l: Lace on my helme againe: what noise is this?
A gentle Ladie flying? the imbrace
Of some vncurteous knight, I will releiue her.
Go squire, and say, the Knight that weares this pestle,
In honour of all Ladies, sweares reuenge
Vpon that recreant coward that pursues her.
Go comfort her, and that same gentle squire
That beares her companie.

sp.speaker: Squire.
sp.l: I go braue Knight.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.l: My trustie Dwarfe and friend, reach me my shield,
And hold it while I sweare: First by my knight-hood,
Then by the soule of Amadis de Gaule,
My famous Ancestor, then by my sword,
The beauteous Brionella girt about me,
By this bright burning pestle of mine honour,
The liuing Trophie, and by all respect
Due to distressed Damsels, here I vow
Neuer to end the quest of this faire Lady,
And that forsaken squire, till by my valour
I gaine their liberty.

sp.speaker: Dwarf.
sp.l: Heauen blesse the Knight
That thus relieues poore errant Gentlewomen.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I marrie Rafe, this has some sauour in't, I would see the proudest of them all offer to carrie his bookes after him. But George, I will not haue him go away so soone, I shall bee sicke if he go away, that I shall; Call Rafe againe George, call Rafe againe, I pre'thee sweet heart let him come fight before me, and let's ha some drums, and some trumpets, and let him kill all that comes neere him, and thou lou'st me George.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Peace a little bird, hee shall kill them all and they were twentie more on 'em then there are.

sp.speaker: Iasp.
sp.l: Now Fortune, if thou bee'st not onely ill,
Shew me thy better face, and bring about
Thy desperate wheele, that I may clime at length
And stand, this is our place of meeting,
If loue haue any constancie. Oh age!
Where onely wealthy men are counted happie:
How shall I please thee? how deserue thy smiles?
When I am onely rich in misery?
My fathers blessing, and this little coine
Is my inheritance, a strong reuenew,
From earth thou art, and to the earth I giue thee,
There grow and multiply, whilst fresher aire,
Breeds me a fresher fortune, how, illusion!
What hath the Diuell coin'd himselfe before me?
'Tis mettle good, it rings well, I am waking,
And taking too I hope, now Gods deere blessing
Vpon his heart that left it here, 'tis mine,
These pearles, I take it, were not left for swine.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I do not like that this vnthrifty youth should embecill away the money; the poore Gentlewoman his mother will haue a heauy heart for it God knowes.

sp.speaker: Cittiz.
sp.p: And reason good, sweet heart.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: But let him go, I'le tell Raph a tale in's eare shall fetch him againe with a Wanion I warrant him, if hee bee aboue ground, and besides George, heere are a number of sufficient Gentlemen can witnesse, and my selfe, and your selfe, and the Musitians, if we be cal'd in question, but here comes Raph, George, thou shalt here him speake, an he were an Emperall.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: Comes not sir Squire againe?

sp.speaker: Dwar.
sp.l: Right courteous Knight,
Your Squire doth come and with him comes the Lady,
sp.stage: Enter mistresse Merr: and Michael, and Squire.
sp.l: For and the Squire of Damsels as I take it.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.l: Madam if any seruice or deuoire
Of a poore errant Knight may right your wrongs,
Command it, I am prest to giue you succour,
For to that holy end I beare my Armour,

sp.speaker: Mist. mer.
sp.p: Alas sir, I am a poore Gentlewoman, and I haue lost my monie in this forrest.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.l: Desart, you would say Lady, and not lost
Whilst I haue sword and launce, dry vp your teares
Which ill befits the beauty of that face:
And tell the storie, if I may request it,
Of your disasterous fortune.

sp.speaker: Mist. mer.
sp.p: Out alas, I left a thousand pound, a thousand pound, e'ne all the monie I had laid vp for this youth, vpon the sight of your Maistership, you lookt so grim, and as I may say it, sauing your presence, more like a Giant then a mortall man.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.l: I am as you are Ladie, so are they
All mortall, but why weepes this gentle Squire.

sp.speaker: Mist. mer.
sp.p: Has hee not cause to weepe doe you thinke, when he hath lost his inheritance?

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.l: Yong hope of valour, weepe not, I am here
That will confound thy foe and paie it deere
Vpon his coward head, that dares denie,
Distressed Squires and Ladies equitie.
I haue but one horse, on which shall ride
This Ladie faire behind me, and before
This courteous Squire, fortune will giue vs more
Vpon our next aduenture; fairelie speed
Beside vs Squire and Dwarfe to do vs need.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Did not I tell you Nel what your man would doe? by the faith of my bodie wench, for cleane action and good deliuerie they may all cast their caps at him.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: And so they may i'faith, for I dare speake it boldly, the twelue Companies of London cannot match him, timber for timber, well George, and hee be not inueigled by some of these paltrie Plaiers, I ha much maruell, but George wee ha done our parts if the boy haue any grace to be thankefull.

sp.speaker: Cittiz.
sp.p: Yes I warrant thee duckling.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: Good Mistresse Luce how euer I in fault am
For your lame horse; you're welcome vnto Waltham.
But which way now to go or what to saie
I know not truely till it be broad daie.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: O feare not Maister Humphrey, I am guide
For this place good enough.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: Then vp and ride,
Or if it please you walke for your repose,
Or sit, or if you will go plucke a rose:
Either of which shall be indifferent,
To your good friend and Humphrey, whose consent
Is so entangled euer to your will,
As the poore harmelesse horse is to the Mill.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Faith and you say the word we'le e'ne sit downe
And take a nap.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: 'Tis better in the Towne,
Where we may nap together, for beleeue me
To sleepe without a snatch would mickle grieue me.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: You're merrie Maister Humphrey.

sp.speaker: Hum,
sp.l: So I am,
And haue bene euer merrie from my Dam.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Your nurce had the lesse labour.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: Faith it may bee,
Vnlesse it were by chance I did beray mee.

sp.speaker: Iasp.
sp.l: Luce deere friend Luce.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Heere Iasper.

sp.speaker: Iasp.
sp.l: You are mine.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: If it be so, my friend, you vse me fine,
What do you thinke I am?

sp.speaker: Iasp.
sp.l: An arrant noddie

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: A word of obloquie, now by Gods bodie,
I'le tell thy maister for I know thee well.

sp.speaker: Iasp.
sp.l: Nay, and you be so forward for to tell,
Take that, and that, and tell him sir I gaue it,
And saie I paid you well.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: O sir I haue it,
And do confesse the paiement, praie be quiet.

sp.speaker: Iasp.
sp.l: Go, get to your night-cap and the diet,
To cure your beaten bones.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Alas poore Humphrie
Get thee some wholsome broth with sage and comfrie:
A little oile of Roses and a feather,
To noint thy backe withall.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: When I came hether,
Would I had gone to Paris with Iohn Dorrie.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Fare-well my prettie Nump, I am verie sorrie
I cannot beare thee companie.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: Fare-well,
The Diuels Dam was ne're so bang'd in hell.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p:
This yong Iasper will proue me another Things, a my conscience and he may be suffered; George, dost not see George how a swaggers, and flies at the very heads a fokes as
he were a Dragon; well if I do not do his lesson for wronging the poore Gentleman, I am no true woman, his friends that brought him vp might haue bene better occupied, I wis, then ha taught him these fegaries, hee's e'ne in the high-way to the gallows, God blesse him.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: You're too bitter, conny, the yong man may do wel enough for all this.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Come hither Maister Humfrey, has hee hurt you? now beshrew his fingers for't, here sweet heart, here's some greene ginger for thee, now beshrew my heart but a has pepper-nel in's head, as big as a pullets egge, alas sweete lamb, how thy Tempels beate; take the peace on him sweete heart, take the peace on him.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: No, no, you talke like a foolish woman, I'le ha Raph fight with him, and swing him vp welfauourdlie, sirrah boie come hither, let Raph come in and fight with Iasper.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I, and beate him well, he's an vnhappy boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Sir you must pardon vs, the plot of our Plaie lies contrarie, and 'twill hazard the spoiling of our Plaie.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Plot mee no plots, I'le ha Raph come out, I'le make your house too hot for you else.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Why sir he shall, but if anie thing fall out of order, the Gentlemen must pardon vs.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Go your waies good-man boie, I'le hold him a pennie hee shall haue his bellie-full of fighting now, ho heere comes Raph, no more.

div.stage: Enter Raph, mistresse Merri: Michael, Squire, and Dwarfe.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: What Knight is that Squire, aske him if he keep
The passage, bound by loue of Ladie faire,
Or else but prickant.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: Sir I am no Knight,
But a poore Gentleman, that this same night,
Had stolne from me on yonder Greene,
My louelie wife, and suffered to be seene
Yet extant on my shoulders such a greeting,
That whilst I liue, I shall thinke of that meeting.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I Raph hee beate him vnmercifully, Raph, and thou spar'st him Raph I would thou wert hang'd.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.l: No more, wife no more.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.l: Where is the caitife wretch hath done this deed.
Lady your pardon, that I may proceed
Vpon the quest of this iniurious Knight.
And thou faire Squire repute me not the worse,
In leauing the great venture of the purse,
And the rich casket till some better leasure,

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: Here comes the Broker hath purloin'd my treasure.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: Go, Squire, and tell him I am here,
An Errant Knight at Armes, to craue deliuery
Of that faire Lady to her owne Knights armes.
If he deny, bid him take choice of ground,
And so defye him.

sp.speaker: Squire.
sp.l: From the Knight that beares
The golden Pestle, I defie thee Knight.
Vnlesse thou make faire restitution.
Of that bright Lady.

sp.speaker: Iasp.
sp.l: Tell the Knight that sent thee
Hee is an Asse, and I will keepe the wench
And knocke his Head-peece.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: Knight, thou art but dead,
If thou thou recall not thy vncurteous tearmes.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Breake's pate Raph, breake's pate Raph, soundly.

sp.speaker: Iasper.
sp.l: Come Knight, I am ready for you, now your Pestel
Shall try what temper, sir, your Morters off
With that he stood vpright in his stirrops,
And gaue the Knight of the Calue-skinne such a knocke,
That he forsooke his horse and downe he fell,
And then he leaped vpon him and plucking of his Helmet.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: Nay, and my noble Knight be downe so soone,
Though I can scarely go I needs must runne.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Runne Raph, runne Raph, runne for thy life boy, Iasper comes, Iasper comes.

sp.speaker: Iasper.
sp.p: Come Luce, we must haue other Armes for you, Humphery and Golden Pestle both adiew.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p:
Sure the diuell, God blesse vs, is in this Springald,
why George, didst euer see such a fire-drake, I am afraid my boie's miscaried, if he be, though hee were Maister Mery-thoughts sonne a thousand times, if there bee any Law in England I'le make some of them smart for't.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: No, no, I haue found out the matter sweete-heart, Iasper is inchanted, as sure as we are heere, he is inchanted, he could no more haue stood in Raph's hands, then I can stand in my Lord Maiors, I'le haue a ring to discouer all inchantments, and Raph shall beate him yet: be no more vext for it shall be so.

div.stage: Enter Raph, Squire, Dwarfe, mistresse Mery-thought and Michaell.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: O husband heere's Raph againe, stay Raph let mee speake with thee, how dost thou Raph? art thou not shrodly hurt? the soule great Lunge is laid vnmercifully on thee, there's some suger-candy for thee, proceed, thou shalt haue another bout with him.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: If Raph had him at the Fencing-schoole, if hee did not make a puppy of him, and driue him vp and downe the schoole he should nere come in my shop more.

sp.speaker: Mist. mer.
sp.p: Truely Maister Knight of the Burning Pestle I am weary.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.p: Indeed law mother and I am very hungry.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: Take comfort gentle Dame, and you faire Squire,
For in this Desart there must needs be plac't,
Many strong Castles, held by curteous Knights,
And till I bring you safe to one of those,
Is weare by this my Order nere to leaue you.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Well said Raph, George, Raph was euer comfortable, was he not?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Yes Ducke.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I shall nere forget him, when wee had lost our child, you know, it was straid almost, alone, to Puddle-wharfe and the Criers were abroad for it, and there it had drown'd it selfe but for a Sculler, Raph was the most comfortablest to me: peace Mistresse, saies he, let it go, I'le get you another as good, did he not George? did he not say so?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Yes indeed did he mouse.

sp.speaker: Dwarfe.
sp.p: I would we had a messe of Pottage, and a pot of drinke, Squire, and were going to bed.

sp.speaker: Squire.
sp.p: Why we are at Waltham Townes end, and that's the Bell Inne.

sp.speaker: Dwarfe.
sp.l: Take courage valiant Knight, Damsel, & Squire
I haue discouered, not a stones cast off,
An ancient Castle held by the old Knight
Of the most holy order of the Bell,
Who giues to all Knights errant entertaine:
There plenty is of food, and all prepar'd,
By the white hands of his owne Lady deere.
He hath three Squires that welcome all his Guests.
The first high Chamberlino, who will see
Our beds prepar'd, and bring vs snowy sheetes,
Where neuer foote-man stretch'd his butter'd Hams.
The second hight Tastero, who will see
Our pots full filled and no froth therein.
The third a gentle Squire Ostlero hight,
Who will our Palfries slicke with wisps of straw,
And in the Maunger put them Oates enough,
And neuer grease their teeth with candle snuffe.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: That same Dwarfe's a pretty boy, but the Squire's a grout-nole.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: Knocke at the Gates my Squire with stately launce.

sp.speaker: Tap.
sp.l: Who's there, you're welcome Gentlemen, will you see a roome?

sp.speaker: Dwarfe.
sp.l: Right curteous and valiant Knight of the burning Pestle,
This is the Squire Tapstero.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: Faire Squire Tapstero, I a wandring Knight,
Hight of the burning Pestle, in the quest
Of this faire Ladies Casket, and wrought purse,
Loosing my selfe in this vast Wildernesse
Am to this Castle well by fortune brought,
Where hearing of the goodly entertaine
Your Knight of holy Order of the Bell
Giues to all Damsels, and all errant Knights,
I thought to knocke, and now am bold to enter.

sp.speaker: Tapster.
sp.p: An't please you see a chamber, you are very welcome.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: George I would haue something done, and I cannot tell what it is.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: What is it Nel?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Why George, shall Raph beate no body againe? prethee sweete-heart let him.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: So he shall Nel, and if I ioyne with him, wee'le knocke them all.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: O George here's maister Humphery againe now, that lost Mistresse Luce, and Mistresse Lucies father, Maister Humphery will do some-bodies errant I warrant him.

sp.speaker: Humf.
sp.l: Father, it's true, in armes I nere shall claspe her,
For shee is stolne away by your man Iasper.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: I thought he would tell him.

sp.speaker: March.
sp.l: Vnhappy that I am to loose my child,
Now I beginne to thinke on Iaspers words,
Who oft hath vrg'd to me thy foolishnesse,
Why didst thou let her go? thou loust her not,
That wouldst bring home thy life, and not bring her.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: Father forgiue me, shall I tell you true,
Looke on my shoulders they are blacke and blew.
Whilst too and fro faire Luce and I were winding,
Hee came and basted me with a hedge binding.

sp.speaker: March.
sp.l: Get men and horses straight, we will be there
Within this houre, you know the place againe.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: I know the place, where he my loines did swaddle,
I'le get six horses, and to each a saddle.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Meane time I'le go talke with Iaspers father.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: George, what wilt thou laye with mee now, that Maister Humphery has not Mistresse Luce yet, speake George, what wilt thou laie with me?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: No Nel, I warrant thee Iasper is at Puckeridge with her, by this.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p:
Nay George, you must consider Mistresse Lucies
feete are tender, and, besides, 'tis darke, and I promise you tuely, I doe not see how hee should get out of Waltham forrest with her yet.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Nay Cunny, what wilt thou laie with me that Raph has her not yet.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I will not lay against Raph hunny, because I haue not spoken with him, but looke George, peace, heere comes the merry old Gentleman againe.

sp.speaker: Old mer.
sp.l: When it was growne to darke midnight,
And all were fast asleepe,
In came Margarets grimely Ghost,
And stood at Williams feete.
sp.p: I haue mony, and meate and drinke before hand, till to morrow at noone, why should I be sad? mee thinkes I haue halfe a dozen Iouiall spirits within mee, I am three merry men, and three merry men, To what end should any man be sad in this world? giue me a man that when hee goes to hanging cries, troule the blacke bowle to mee: and a woeman that will sing a cath in her Trauell. I haue seene a man come by my dore, with a serious face, in a blacke cloake, without a hat-band, carrying his head as if hee lookt for pinnes in the streete, I haue lookt out of my window halfe a yeare after, and haue spide that mans head vpon London-bridge: 'tis vile, neuer trust a Tailor that does not sing at his worke, his mind is of nothing but filching.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Marke this George, tis worth noting: Godfrry my Tailor, you know, neuer sings, and hee had foureteene yards to make this Gowne, and I'le be sworne Mistresse Pennistone the Drapers wife had one made with twelue.

sp.speaker: Old men:
sp.l: 'Tis mirth that fils the veines with bloud,
More then wine, or sleepe, or food.
Let each man keepe his heart at ease,
No man dies of that disease.
He that would his body keepe
From diseases, must not weepe,
But who euer laughes and sings,
Neuer he his body brings
Into feuers, gouts, or rhumes,
Or lingringly his longs consumes:
Or meets with aches in the bone,
Or Catharhes, or griping stone:
But contented liues for aye,
The more he laughes, the more he may.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Looke George, how saist thou by this George? is't not a fine old man? Now Gods blessing a'thy sweet lips. When wilt thou be so merry George? Faith thou art the frowningst little thing when thou art angry, in a Countrey.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Peace Coney, thou shalt see him taken downe too I warrant thee; here's Luces father come now.

sp.speaker: Old mer.
sp.p: As you came from Walsingham, from that holy land, there met you not with my tru-loue by the way as you came

sp.speaker: March.
sp.l: Oh Maister Merri-thought! my daughter's gone.
This mirth becomes you not, my daughters gone.

sp.speaker: Old merri.
sp.l: Why an if she be, what care I?
Or let her come or go, or tarry.

sp.speaker: March.
sp.l: Mocke not my misery, it is your sonne,
Whom I haue made my owne, when all forsooke him,
Has stolne my onely ioy, my childe away.

sp.speaker: Old mer.
sp.l: He set her on a milk-white steed, & himselfe vpon a gray,
He neuer turn'd his face againe, but he bore her quite away.

sp.speaker: March.
sp.l: Vnworthy of the kindnesse I haue shewn
To thee, and thine: too late I well perceiue
Thou art consenting to my daughters losse.

sp.speaker: Old mer.
sp.p: Your daughter, what a stur's here wee yer daughter? Let her goe, thinke no more on her, but sing lowd. If both my sons were on the gallows, I would sing, downe, down, downe: they fall downe, and arise they neuer shall.

sp.speaker: March.
sp.l: Oh might I behold her once againe,
And she once more embrace her aged sire.

sp.speaker: Old merri.
sp.p: Fie, how scuruily this goes: and she once more imbrace her aged sire? you'l make a dogge on her, will yee? she cares much for her aged sire I warrant you.
sp.l: She cares cares not for her daddy, nor shee cares not for her mammie,
For she is, she is, she is, she is my Lord of Low-gaues Lassie.

sp.speaker: March.
sp.l: For this thy scorne, I will pursue
That sonne of thine to death.

sp.speaker: Old merri.
sp.l: Do, and when you ha kild him,
Giue him flowers i'now Palmer: giue him flowers i'now,
Giue him red, and white, and blew, greene, and yellow.

sp.speaker: March.
sp.l: Il'e fetch my daughter.

sp.speaker: Old merri.
sp.p: Il'e heare no more a your daughter, it spoyles my mirth.

sp.speaker: March.
sp.l: I say Il'e fetch my daughter.

sp.speaker: Old merri.
sp.l: Was neuer man for Ladies sake, downe, downe,
Tormented as I poore sir Guy? de derry downe,
For Lucies sake, that Lady bright, downe, downe,
As euer men beheld with eye? de derry downe.

sp.speaker: March.
sp.l: Il'e be reueng'd by heauen.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: How do'st thou like this George?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Why this is well coney: but if Raph were hot once, thou shouldst see more.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: The Fidlers go againe husband.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: I Nell, but this is scuruy musicke: I gaue the whoreson gallowes money, and I thinke hee has not got mee the waits of South-warke, if I heare him not anan, Il'e twinge him by the eares. You Musicians, play Baloo.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: No good George, lets ha Lachrimae.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Why this is it cony.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: It's all the better George: now sweet lambe, what story is that painted vpon the cloth? the confutation of Saint Paul?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: No lambe, that's Raph and Lucrece.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Raph and Lucrece? which Raph? our Raph?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: No mouse, that was a Tartarian.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: A Tartarian? well, I'wood the fidlers had done, that wee might see our Raph againe.

div.head: Actus tertius,
Scoena prima.

sp.speaker: Iasp.
sp.l: Come my deere deere, though we haue lost our way,
We haue not lost our selues: are you not weary
With this nights wandring, broken from your rest?
And frighted with the terrour that attends
The darknesse of these wilde vn-peopled place?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: No my best friend, I cannot either feare,
Or entertaine a weary thought, whilst you
(The end of all my full desires) stand by me.
Let them that loose their hopes, and liue to languish
Amongst the number of forsaken louers,
Tell the long weary steps, and number time,
Start at a shadow, and shrinke vp their bloud,
Whilst I (possest with all content and quiet)
Thus take my prettie loue, and thus imbrace him.

sp.speaker: Iasp.
sp.l: You haue caught me Luce, so fast, that whilst I liue
I shall become your faithfull prisoner,
And were these chaines for euer. Come sit downe,
And rest your body, too too delicate
For these disturbances; so, will you sleepe?
Come, do not be more able then you are,
I know you are not skilfull in these watches:
For women are no souldiers; be not nice,
But take it, sleepe I say.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: I cannot sleepe,
Indeed I cannot friend.

sp.speaker: Iasp.
sp.l: Why then wee'l sing,
And try how that will worke vpon our sences.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Il'e sing, or say, or any thing but sleepe.

sp.speaker: Ias.
sp.l: Come little Mer-maid, rob me of my heart
With that inchanting voyce.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: You mocke me Iasper.

sp.speaker: Iasp.
sp.l: Tell me (deerest) what is loue?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: 'Tis a lightning from aboue,
'Tis an arrow, 'tis a fire,
'Tis a boy they call desire.
'Tis a smile
Doth beguile

sp.speaker: Ias.
sp.l: The poore hearts of men that proue.
Tell me more, are women true?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Some loue change, and so do you.

sp.speaker: Ias.
sp.l: Are they faire, and neuer kind?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Yes, when men turne with the winde.

sp.speaker: Ias.
sp.l: Are they froward?

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Euer toward,
Those that loue, to loue a new.

sp.speaker: Ias.
sp.l: Dissemble it no more, I see the God
Of heauy sleepe, lay on his heauy mace
Vpon your eye-lids.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: I am very heauy.

sp.speaker: Iasp.
sp.l: Sleep, sleep, & quiet rest crowne thy sweet thoughts:
Keepe from her faire bloud, distempers, startings,
Horrors, and fearefull shapes: let all her dreames
Be ioyes, and chast delights, imbraces, wishes,
And such new pleasures, as the rauisht soule
Giues to the sences. So, my charmes haue tooke.
Keepe her you powers diuine, whilst I contemplate
Vpon the wealth and beauty of her minde.
She is onely faire, and constant: onely kinde,
And onely to thee Iasper. Oh my ioyes!
Whither will you transport me? let not fulnesse
Of my poore buried hopes, come vp together,
And ouer-charge my spirits: I am weake
Some say( how euer ill) the sea and women
Are gouern'd by the Moone, both ebbe and flow,
Both full of changes: yet to them that know,
And truly iudge, these but opinions are,
And heresies to bring on pleasing warre
Betweene our tempers, that without these were
Both void of ater-loue, and present feare.
Which are the best of Cupid. Oh thou child!
Bred from dispaire, I dare not entertaine thee,
Hauing a loue without the faults of women,
And greater in her perfect goods then men:
Which to make good, and please my selfe the stronger,
Though certainely I am certaine of her loue,
Il'e try her, that the world and memory
May sing to after times, her constancie.
Luce, Luce, awake.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Why do you fright me, friend,
With those distempered lookes? what makes your sword
Drawne in your hand? who hath offended you?
I pre'chee Iasper sleepe, thou art wilde with watching.

sp.speaker: Iasp.
sp.l: Come make your way to heauen, and bid the world
(With all the villanies that sticke vpon it)
Fare-well; you'r for another life.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Oh Iasper!
How haue my tender yeares committed euill,
(Especially against the man I loue)
Thus to be cropt vntimely?

sp.speaker: Iasp.
sp.l: Foolish girle,
Canst thou imagine I could loue his daughter,
That flung me from my fortune into nothing?
Discharged me his seruice, shut the doores
Vpon my pouerty, and scorn'd my prayers,
Sending me, like a boat without a mast,
To sinke or swin? Come, by this hand you dye,
I must haue life and bloud to satisfie
Your fathers wrongs.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Away George, away, raise the watch at Ludgate, and bring a Mittimus from the Iustice for this desperate villaine. Now I charge you Gentlemen, see the Kings peace kept. O my heart what a varlet's this to offer man-slaughter vpon the harmelesse Gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: I warrant thee (sweet heart) wee'l haue him hampered.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Oh Iasper! be not cruell,
If thou wilt kill me, mile and do it quickly.
And let not many deaths appeare before me.
I am a woman made of feare and loue,
A weake, weake woman, kill not with thy eyes,
They shoot me through and through. Strike I am ready,
And dying stil I loue thee.

div.stage: Enter Merchant, Humphrey, and his men.

sp.speaker: March.
sp.l: Where abouts.

sp.speaker: Iasp.
sp.l: No more of this, now to my selfe againe.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: There, there he stands with sword like martial knight
Drawne in his hand, therefore beware the fight
You that be wise: for were I good sir Beuis,
I would not stay his comming, by your leaues.

sp.speaker: March.
sp.l: Sirrah, restore my daughter.

sp.speaker: Iasp.
sp.l: Sirrah, no.

sp.speaker: March.
sp.l: Vpon him then.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: So, downe with him, downe with him, downe with him: cut him i'th leg boies, cut him i'th leg.

sp.speaker: March.
sp.l: Come your waies Minion, Il'e prouide a Cage
For you, your growne so tame. Horse her away.

sp.speaker: Humph.
sp.l: Truly Ime glad your forces haue the day.

sp.speaker: Iasp.
sp.l: They are gone, and I am hurt, my loue is lost,
Neuer to get againe. Oh me vnhappy!
Bleed, bleed, and dye, I cannot: Oh my folly!
Thou hast betraid me. Hope where art thou fled?
Tell me if thou bee'st any where remaining.
Shall I but see my loue againe? Oh no!
She will not daine to looke vpon her butcher,
Nor is it fit she should; yet I must venter.
Oh chance, or fortune, or what ere thou art
That men adore for powerfull, heare my cry,
And let me louing, liue; or loosing, die.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Is a gone George?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: I conie.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Marie and let him goe (sweet heart,) by the faith a my body a has put me into such a fright, that I tremble (as they say) as 'twere an Aspine leafe: looke a my little singer George, how it shakes: now i truth euery member of my body is the worse for't.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p:
Come, hugge in mine armes sweet mouse, hee shall
not fright thee any more: alas mine owne deere heart, how it quiuers.

div.stage: Enter Mistresse Merrithought, Rafe, Michall, Squire Dwarfe, Host, and a Tapster.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: O Rafe, how dost thou Rafe? how hast thou slept to night? has the knight vs'd thee well?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.l: Peace Nell, let Rafe alone.

sp.speaker: Tapst.
sp.l: Maister, the reckoning is not paid.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.l: Right curteous knight, who for the orders sake
Which thou hast tane, hang'st out the holy bell,
As I this flaming pestle beare about,
We render thankes to your puissant selfe,
Your beauteous Lady, and your gentle Squires,
For thus refreshing of our wearied limbes,
Stiffned with hard atchieuements in wilde desert.

sp.speaker: Tapst.
sp.l: Sir, there is twelue shillings to pay.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.l: Thou merry Squire Tapstero, thankes to thee,
For comforting our soules with double Iug,
And if aduentrous fortune pricke thee forth,
Thou Iouiall Squire, to follow feats of armes,
Take heed thou tender euery Ladies cause,
Euery truery true Knight, and euery damsell faire faire;
But spill the bloud of trecherous Sarazens,
And false inchanters, that with magicke spels,
Haue done to death full many a noble Knight.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Thou valiant Knight of the burning Pestle, giue eare to me, there is twelue shillings to pay, and as I am a true Knight, I will not bate a peny.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: George, I pray thee tell me, must Rafe pay twelue shillings now?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: No Nell, no, nothing but the old Knight is merrie with Rafe.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: O is't nothing else? Rafe will be as merry as he.

sp.speaker: Rafe.
sp.l: Sir Knight, this mirth of yours becomes you well,
But to requite this liberall curtesie,
If any of your Squires will follow armes,
Hee shall receiue from my heroicke hand
A Knight-hood, by the vertue of this Pestle.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Faire Knight I thanke you for noble offer,
Therefore gentle Knight,
Twelue shillings you must pay, or I must cap you.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Looke George, did not I tell thee as much, the Knight of the Bel is in earnest, Raph shall not bee beholding to him, giue him his money George, and let him go snickvp.

sp.speaker: Ci.
sp.p: Cap Raph? no; hold your hand sir Knight of the Bel, theres your mony, haue you any thing to say to Raph now? Cap Raph?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I would you should know it, Raph has friends that will not suffer him to be capt for ten times so much, and tea times to the end of that, now take thy course Raph.

sp.speaker: M. mer.
sp.p: Come Michael, thou & I wil go home to thy father, he hath enough left to keep vs a day or two, and we'le set fellows abrod to cry our Purse & our Casket, Shal we Michael?

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.p: I, I pray Mother, intruth my feete are full of chilblaines with trauelling.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Faith and those chilblanes are a foule trouble, Mistresse Merie-thought when your youth comes home let him rub all the soles of his feete, and the heeles, and his ancles, with a mouse skinne, or if none of your people can catch a mouse, when hee goes to bed, let him rowle his feete in the warme embers, aud I warrant you hee shall be well, and you may make him put his fingers betweene his toes & smell to them, it's very soueraigne for his head if he be costiue.

sp.speaker: Mist. mer.
sp.p: Maister Knight of the burning Pestle, my son Michael and I, bid you farewel, I thanke your Worship heartily for your kindnesse.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: Fare-well faire Lady and your tender Squire,
If, pricking through these Desarts, I do heare
Of any traiterous Knight who through his guile,
Hath light vpon your Casket and your Purse,
I will despoile him of them and restore them.

sp.speaker: Mist. mer.
sp.l: I thanke your Worship.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: Dwarfe beare my shield, Squire eleuate my lance,
And now fare-well you Knight of holy Bell.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.l: I, I Raph, all is paid.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: But yet before I go, speake worthy Knight,
If ought you do of sad aduentures know,
Where errant Knights may through his prowesse winne,
Eternall fame and free some gentle soules,
From endlesse bonds of steele and lingring paine.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Sirrah go to Nicke the Barbor, and bid him prepare himselfe, as I told you before, quickely.

sp.speaker: Tap.
sp.p: I am gone sir.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Sir Knight, this wildernesse affoordeth none
But the great venter, where full many a Knight
Hath tride his prowesse and come off with shame,
And where I would not haue you loose your life,
Against no man, but furious fiend of hell.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: Speake on sir Knight, tell what he is, and where,
For heere I vow vpon my blazing badge,
Neuer to blaze a day in quietnesse;
But bread and water will I onely eate,
And the greene hearbe and rocke shall be my couch,
Till I haue queld that man, or beast, or fiend,
That workes such damage to all Errant Knights.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Not far from hence, neere to a craggy cliffe,
At the North end of this distressed Towne,
There doth stand a lowly house
Ruggedly builded, and in it a Caue,
In which an ougly Gyant now doth won,
Yeleped Barbaroso: in his hand
He shakes a naked lance of purest steele,
With sleeues turn'd vp, and him before he weares,
A motley garment, to preserue his cloaths
From bloud of those Knights which he massacres,
And Ladies Gent: without his dore doth hang
A copper balon, on a piickant speare:
At which, no sooner gentle Knights can knocke,
But the shrill sound, fierce Barbaroso heares,
And rushing forth, brings in the errant Knight,
And sets him downe in an inchanted chaire.
Then with an Engine which he hath prepar'd,
With forty teeth, he clawes his courtly crowne,
Next makes him winke, and vnderneath his chinne,
Hee plants a brazen peece of mighty bord,
And knocks his bullets round about his cheeks,
Whilst with his fingers, and an instrument
With which he snaps his haire off, he doth fill
The wretches eares with a most hideous noise.
Thus euery Knight Aduenturer he doth trim,
And now no creature dares encounter him.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: In Gods name, I will fight him, kinde sir,
Go but before me to this dismall Caue,
Where this huge Gyant Barbaroso dwels,
And by that vertue that braue Rosicleere,
That damned brood of ougly Gyants slew,
And Palmerin Frannarco ouerthrew:
I doubt not but to curbe this Traitor foule,
And to the Diuell send his guilty soule.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Braue sprighted Knight, thus far I will performe.
This your request, I'le bring you with in sight
Of this most lothsome place, inhabited
By a more loathsome man: but dare not stay,
For his maine force soopes all he sees away.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: Saint George set on before, march Squire and page.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: George, dost thinke Raph will confound the Gyant?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: I hold my cap to a farthing hee does: why Nel I saw him wrastle with the great Dutch-man and hurle him.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Faith and that Ducth-man was a goodly man, if all things were answerable to his bignesse, and yet they say there was a Scotsh-man higher then hee, and that they two and a Knight met, and saw one another for nothing, but of all the sights that euer were in London, since I was married, mee thinkes the little child that was so faire growne about the members was the prettiest, that, and the Hermophrodite.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Nay by your leaue Nel, Niniuy was better.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Niniuie, O that was the story of Ione and the Wall, was it not George?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Yes lam.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Looke George, heere comes Mistresse Merry-thought againe, and I would haue Raph come and fight with the Giant, I tell you true, I long to see't.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Good Mistresse Merry-thought be gone, I pray you for my sake, I pray you forbeare a little, you shall haue audience presently, I haue a little businesse.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Mistresse Merry-thought if it please you to refraine your passion a little, til Raph haue dispatch the Giant out of the way we shal think our selues much bound to you, I thank you good Mistresse Merry-thought.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Boy, come hither, send away Raph and this whore-sonne Giant quickely.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: In good faith sir we cannot, you'le vtterly spoile our Play, and make it to be hist, and it cost money, you will not suffer vs to go on with our plot, I pray Gentlemen rule him.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Let him come now and dispatch this, and I'le trouble you no more.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Will you giue me your hand of that?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Giue him thy hand George, do, and I'le kisse him, I warrant thee the youth meanes plainely.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I'le send him to you presently.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I thanke you little youth, feth the child hath a sweete breath George, but I thinke it bee troubled with the wormes, Carduus Benedictus and Mares milke were the onely thing in the world for't, O Raph's here George, God send thee good lucke Raph.

div.stage: Enter Raph, Host, Squire, and Dwarfe.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Puissant Knight yonder his Mansion is,
Lo where the speare and Copper Bason are,
Behold that string on which hangs many a tooth,
Drawne from the gentle iaw of wandring Knights,
I dare not stay to sound, hee will appeare.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: O faint not heart, Susan my Lady deere,
The Coblers Maid in Milke-streete, for whose sake,
I take these Armes, O let the thought of thee,
Carry thy Knight through all aduenterous deeds,
And in the honor of thy beauteous selfe,
May I destroy this monster Barbaroso,
Knocke Squire vpon the Bason till it breake.
With the shrill stroakes, or till the Giant speake.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: O George, the Giant, the Giant, now Raph for thy life.

sp.speaker: Barber.
sp.l: What fond vnknowing wight is this? that dares
So rudely knocke at Barbarossa's Cell,
Where no man comes but leaues his fleece behind?

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.l: I, traiterous Caitiffe, who am sent by fate
To punish all the sad enormities
Thou hast committed against Ladies Gent
And errant Knights, traitor to God and men:
Prepare thy selfe, this is the dismall houre
Appointed for thee, to giue strickt account
Of all thy beastly treacherous villanies.

sp.speaker: Barber.
sp.l: Foole-hardy Knight, full soone thou shalt aby
This fond reproach, thy body will I bang,
And loe vpon that string thy teeth shall hang:
Prepare thy selfe, for dead soone shalt thou bee,

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.p: Saint George for me.

sp.speaker: Barber.
sp.p: Gargantua for me.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: To him, Raph to him, hold vp the Giant, set out thy leg before Raph.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Falsifie a blow Raph, falsifie a blow, the Giant lies open on the left side.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Beare't off, beare't of still; there boy, O Raphe's almost downe, Raph's almost downe.

sp.speaker: Raph.
sp.p: Susan inspire me, now haue vp againe.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Vp, vp, vp, vp, vp, so Raph, downe with him, downe with him Raph.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Fetch him ore the hip boy.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: There boy, kill, kill, kill, kill, kill, Raph.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: No Raph get all out of him first.
